intro: Ischaemum crassipes var. hondae, commonly known as the Honduran roughgrass, is a variant of the species native to Central America. It is a perennial grass characterized by its coarse, fibrous stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. This plant typically grows in moist, disturbed habitats such as riverbanks and wetlands. Its inflorescence consists of spikelets that are often clustered in loose, open panicles. The botanical features of Ischaemum crassipes var. hondae make it adaptable to wet environments and contribute to its ecological significance in its native range.
